<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>13.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Convertible Debt and Line of Credit</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The convertible debt balance was $0 and $347.4&nbsp;million, net
of accumulated fair value adjustment of $0 and $2.4&nbsp;million
(see Note&nbsp;7), at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Zero Coupon Convertible Debentures Due 2018</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In February 1998, the Company completed a private placement of
zero coupon convertible subordinated debentures due in 2018 (the
&#147;Debentures&#148;). The Debentures, with an aggregate face
amount at maturity of $885.5&nbsp;million, generated net
proceeds to the Company of approximately $337.6&nbsp;million.
The initial price to the public for the debentures was
$391.06&nbsp;per $1,000 of face amount at maturity, which
equates to a yield to maturity over the term of the Debentures
of 4.75% (on a semi-annual Debentures equivalent basis). The
Debentures were convertible into common stock at the rate of
8.538&nbsp;shares per $1,000 of face amount at maturity, which
equated to an initial conversion price of $45.80&nbsp;per share.
The Debentures were subordinated in right of payment to all
existing and future Senior Indebtedness (as defined in the
related indenture) and effectively subordinated in right of
payment to all indebtedness and other liabilities of the
Company&#146;s subsidiaries.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In accordance with the indenture, in 2002, the Company redeemed
a portion of the Debentures, which had an aggregate face amount
at maturity of $140.0&nbsp;million, at a net price of
$66.2&nbsp;million, which was financed from the Company&#146;s
investment portfolio. In connection with this repurchase, the
Company recognized a net gain of approximately $26,000 in 2002.
The gain was calculated as the difference between the accreted
value of the debt, net of unamortized issuance costs and the
cost of repurchase.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In February 2003, outstanding Debentures, with an aggregate face
amount at maturity of $358.5&nbsp;million, became redeemable for
cash at the option of the holders thereof, at which time the
Company repurchased Debentures which had an aggregate face
amount at maturity of $358.0&nbsp;million for a net price of
$177.1&nbsp;million. In June 2003, the Company repurchased the
remaining Debentures with an aggregate face amount at maturity
of $0.5&nbsp;million for a net price of $0.2&nbsp;million. The
Company recognized a loss of $2.7&nbsp;million on the repurchase
of Debentures during 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>5.25%&nbsp;Convertible Subordinated Note&nbsp;Due
    2006</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In August 2001, the Company issued 5.25%&nbsp;convertible
subordinated notes (&#147;Notes&#148;) due 2006 with an
aggregate principal amount of $345.0&nbsp;million. The issuance
generated net proceeds (after deducting fees and expenses) of
$335.1&nbsp;million. The amortization of the issuance costs
related to the Notes has been calculated using the effective
interest method and recorded as additional interest expense in
the statements of income. The Notes were unsecured and were
subordinated to all existing and future Senior Indebtedness (as
defined in the related indenture). The Notes had no restrictive
financial covenants.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">103

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>MCAFEE, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Notes had a maturity date of August&nbsp;15, 2006, unless
earlier redeemed by the Company at its option or converted at
the holder&#146;s option. At the option of the holder, the Notes
were convertible into the Company&#146;s common stock at any
time, unless previously redeemed, at a conversion price of
$18.07&nbsp;per share. The Notes could also be redeemed at the
option of the holder in the event of a Change of Control (as
defined in the related indenture). At any time between
August&nbsp;20, 2004 and August&nbsp;14, 2005, the Company would
be able to redeem all or a portion of the Notes for cash at a
repurchase price of 101.3125% of the principal amount. After
August&nbsp;14, 2005, the repurchase price would be 100.0% of
the principal amount.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In August 2004, the Company redeemed all of the outstanding
Notes at a net price of $265.6&nbsp;million. Prior to the
redemption date, approximately $83.4&nbsp;million in aggregate
principal amount of the Notes converted into approximately
4.6&nbsp;million shares of the Company&#146;s common stock. The
Company recorded a loss on redemption of approximately
$15.1&nbsp;million, which represented the write-off of
unamortized debt issuance costs, fair value adjustment and the
1.3125% premium paid for redemption.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In July 2002, the Company entered into an interest rate swap
transaction with two investment banks, which resulted in the
convertible notes being carried at fair value (see Note&nbsp;7).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The estimated fair value of the Company&#146;s long-term debt
outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2003, which consisted of Notes
with a carrying amount of $347.4, was $373.1&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Line of Credit</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company has a $17.0&nbsp;million credit facility with a
bank. The credit facility is available on an offering basis,
meaning that transactions under the credit facility will be on
such terms and conditions, including interest rate, maturity,
representations, covenants and events of default, as mutually
agreed between the Company and the bank at the time of each
specific transaction. The credit facility is intended to be used
for short term credit requirements, with terms of one year or
less. The credit facility can be cancelled at any time. No
balances are outstanding as of December&nbsp;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>14.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Employee Benefit Plans</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Company 401(k) and Profit Sharing Plan</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s 401(k) and Profit Sharing Plan cover
substantially all full-time employees. Employees can elect to
defer the lesser of 40% of their compensation or
$13,000&nbsp;per year. The board of directors, at its
discretion, can match employee contributions in an amount not to
exceed a maximum of $4,000&nbsp;per year. The number of plan
participants was impacted by headcount reductions resulting from
the Magic and Sniffer dispositions, as well as general headcount
reductions. Annual amounts contributed by the Company under the
plan were $4.0&nbsp;million, $4.7&nbsp;million, and
$4.3&nbsp;million in 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Company Employee Stock Purchase Plan</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In April 2002, the Company&#146;s board of directors adopted
McAfee&#146;s 2002 Employee Stock Purchase Plan (&#147;2002
Purchase Plan&#148;) and an initial 2.0&nbsp;million shares of
the Company&#146;s common stock were reserved for issuance. In
December 2003, the Company&#146;s stockholders approved an
additional 2.0&nbsp;million shares for issuance under the 2002
Purchase Plan for a total of 4.0&nbsp;million shares. All
employees are eligible to participate in the 2002 Purchase Plan.
The 2002 Purchase Plan is comprised of two year offering periods
with four six-month purchase periods. Purchase periods occur
twice yearly and each offering effectively contains a six,
twelve, eighteen and twenty-four month option. Shares are
purchased through employees&#146; contributions at exercise
prices equal to 85% of the lesser of the fair market value of
the Company&#146;s common stock at either the first day of an
offering period or the last day of the purchase period. No
participant may purchase more than $25,000 of common stock in
any one calendar year and the maximum number of shares a
participant may purchase during a single offering period is
10,000&nbsp;shares. In 2004 and 2003, approximately
0.8&nbsp;million and
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">104

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>MCAFEE, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
1.6&nbsp;million shares were issued under the 2002 Purchase Plan
at a weighted average purchase price of $10.41 and $9.89,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the 1994 Employee Qualified Stock Purchase Plan
(&#147;1994 Purchase Plan&#148;), the Company could grant stock
purchase rights to all eligible employees during one year
offering periods with exercise dates approximately every six
months (beginning each August and February). The Company had
reserved 3.8&nbsp;million shares of common stock for issuance
under the plan. Shares were purchased through employees&#146;
payroll deductions at exercise prices equal to 85% of the lesser
of the fair value of the Company&#146;s common stock at either
the first day of an offering period or the last day of such
offering period. No participant could purchase more than $25,000
of common stock in any one calendar year. After the purchase on
January&nbsp;31, 2002, the 1994 Purchase Plan was terminated. In
2002, approximately 0.7&nbsp;million shares were issued under
the 1994 Purchase Plan at a weighted average purchase price of
$7.24.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>McAfee.com Employee Stock Purchase Plan</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In September 1999, McAfee.com&#146;s board of directors adopted
McAfee.com&#146;s Employee Stock Purchase Plan (the &#147;1999
Purchase Plan&#148;). A total of 0.5&nbsp;million shares of
McAfee.com Class&nbsp;A common stock were initially reserved for
issuance under the 1999 Purchase Plan. All McAfee.com full-time
employees were eligible to participate in the 1999 Purchase
Plan. The 1999 Purchase Plan was comprised of two-year offering
periods with exercise dates approximately every six months
(beginning each August and February), with the exception of the
first offering period, which commenced on December&nbsp;2, 1999,
with the first exercise date on January&nbsp;31, 2000. Shares
were purchased through McAfee.com employees&#146; payroll
deductions at exercise prices equal to 85% of the lesser of the
fair market value of McAfee.com&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock
at either the first day of an offering period or the last day of
such offering period. No participant could purchase more than
$25,000 worth of Class&nbsp;A common stock in any one calendar
year and the maximum number of shares a participant could
purchase during a single purchase period was 2,500&nbsp;shares.
Purchase periods occurred twice yearly and each offering
effectively contained a six, twelve, eighteen and twenty-four
month option. On September&nbsp;13, 2002, the Company acquired
the minority interest in McAfee.com and therefore the McAfee.com
employee stock purchase plan was terminated. In 2002,
approximately 0.2&nbsp;million of McAfee.com shares were issued
under the 1999 Purchase Plan at weighted average purchase price
of $6.66. There was no activity under this plan in 2004 and 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>15.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Stockholders&#146; Equity</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Common Stock</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In November 2003, the Company&#146;s board of directors
authorized the repurchase up to $150.0&nbsp;million of the
Company&#146;s common stock in the open market. In August 2004,
the board of directors authorized the repurchase of an
additional $200.0&nbsp;million of common stock through August
2006. The Company repurchased approximately 12.6&nbsp;million
and 0.4&nbsp;million shares of its common stock in 2004 and 2003
for $221.8&nbsp;million and $4.7&nbsp;million, respectively. As
of December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company may repurchase an
additional $123.6&nbsp;million of its common stock. The timing
and size of future repurchases are subject to market conditions,
stock prices, the Company&#146;s cash position and other cash
requirements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 2004, the Company retired approximately 13.0&nbsp;million
shares of its common stock which had been purchased on the open
market in 2003 and 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 1998, the Company deposited approximately 1.7&nbsp;million
shares of common stock with a trustee for the benefit of the
employees of the Dr.&nbsp;Solomon&#146;s acquisition to cover
the stock options assumed in the acquisition of this company.
These shares, which have been included in the outstanding share
balance, were to be issued upon the exercise of stock options by
Dr.&nbsp;Solomon&#146;s employees. The Company determined in
June 2004 that Dr.&nbsp;Solomon&#146;s employees had exercised
approximately 1.6&nbsp;million options, and that it had issued
new shares in
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">105

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>MCAFEE, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
connection with these exercises rather than the trust shares.
The trustee returned the 1.6&nbsp;million shares to the Company
in June 2004, at which time they were retired and were no longer
included in the outstanding share balance. In December 2004, the
trustee sold the remaining 133,288&nbsp;shares in the trust for
proceeds of $3.8&nbsp;million, and remitted the funds to the
Company. The terms of the trust prohibited the trustee from
returning the shares to the Company and stipulated that only
employees could benefit from the shares. The Company paid out
the $3.8&nbsp;million to its employees as a bonus in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Preferred Stock</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company has authorized 5.0&nbsp;million shares of preferred
stock, par value $0.01&nbsp;per share. The Company&#146;s board
of directors has authority to provide for the issuance of the
shares of preferred stock in series, to establish from time to
time the number of shares to be included in each such series and
to fix the designation, powers, preferences and rights of the
shares of each such series and the qualifications, limitations
or restrictions thereof, without any further vote or action by
the shareholders.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Company Stock Option Plans</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the amended 1997 Plan, the Company has reserved
32.5&nbsp;million shares for issuance to employees, officers,
directors, third party contractors and consultants. The plan
provides for an option price no less than 100% of the fair value
of the Company&#146;s common stock on the date of grant for
incentive stock options granted to employees and officers
(including directors who are also employees) or 85% of the fair
value on the date of grant for all others. The options may be
exercisable immediately, or over time, but generally become
exercisable 25% one year after commencing employment or from
date of grant and thereafter in monthly increments over three
years. All options under the option plan expire ten years after
grant.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the Stock Option Plan for Outside Directors, the Company
has reserved 1.1&nbsp;million shares of its common stock for
issuance to certain members of its board of directors who are
not employees of the Company or any affiliated corporation. The
plan provides for an option price at fair value of the
Company&#146;s common stock on the date of grant. The initial
grant to each outside director generally vests ratably over a
three-year period. Subsequent option grants will become
exercisable after three years from the date of grant. All
options under the option plan expire ten years after grant.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company assumed the Foundstone, Inc. 2000 Stock Plan as part
of the acquisition of Foundstone in October 2004 (see
Note&nbsp;4). The Company has reserved 747,144&nbsp;shares of
its common stock for issuance under this plan. The plan provides
for an option price no less than 85% of the fair value of the
Company&#146;s common stock on the date of grant. The options
generally become exercisable 25% one year after commencing
employment or from the date of grant and thereafter in monthly
increments over three years. All options under the plan expire
ten years after grant. The Company assumed 428,696 options to
purchase its common stock as a result of the acquisition.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In September 2002, the Company acquired the minority interest in
McAfee.com. At that time, all outstanding options under
McAfee.com&#146;s 1999 Stock Plan and 1999&nbsp;Director Option
Plan were converted and transferred into the Company&#146;s
option plans and the McAfee.com stock option plans were
terminated.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">106

</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net proceeds from exercise of stock options was
$105.7&nbsp;million, $19.6&nbsp;million and $99.7&nbsp;million
for 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively, which is net of a
reduction in stock option exercise proceeds of
$0.5&nbsp;million, $0.9&nbsp;million and $7.8&nbsp;million,
respectively. This reduction is for the payment of the
Company&#146;s cash obligation, not exceeding the full exercise
price, which is triggered upon exercise of the Company stock
options that were granted in exchange for the McAfee.com options
(see Note&nbsp;16).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During 2004 the Company granted 1.1&nbsp;million stock options
to employees for which the exercise price was below the fair
value of its common stock on the date of grant. The Company is
recognizing approximately $0.1&nbsp;million in compensation
expense over the vesting period of the options. During 2002, the
Company exchanged approximately 2.3&nbsp;million options in the
McAfee.com acquisition at exercise prices below fair value as of
the acquisition date (see Note&nbsp;16). No options were granted
to employees below or above fair value during 2003.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">107

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>MCAFEE, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, the Company had
14.1&nbsp;million and 10.0&nbsp;million options that were
exercisable with weighted average exercise prices of $15.33 and
$14.27, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The fair value of options granted by the Company and McAfee.com
has been calculated using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model
using the single option approach. A typical option grant vests
over a four-year period. Parameters for the option analysis are
listed below.
</DIV>

    <TD width="3%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Preferred Shares Rights Agreement</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On October&nbsp;19, 1998, pursuant to a Preferred Shares Rights
Agreement between the Company and BankBoston, N.A. as Rights
Agent, the board of directors of the Company announced that it
had declared a dividend distribution of one preferred share
purchase right (a &#147;Right&#148;) on each outstanding share
of the Company&#146;s common stock. Each Right will entitle
stockholders to buy one one-thousandth of a share of the
Company&#146;s Series&nbsp;B Participating Preferred Stock at an
exercise price of $200.00. The Rights will become exercisable
following the tenth day after a person or group announces the
acquisition of 15% or more of the Company&#146;s common stock or
announces commencement of a tender or exchange offer, the
consummation of which would result in ownership by the person or
group of 15% or more of the common stock of the Company. The
Company will be entitled to redeem the Rights at $0.01&nbsp;per
Right at any time on or before the tenth day following
acquisition by a person or group of 15% or more of the
Company&#146;s common stock. The dividend distribution was made
on November&nbsp;3, 1998, payable to the stockholders of record
on November&nbsp;3, 1998. The Rights expire on October&nbsp;20,
2008.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>16.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Stock-Based Compensation</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company recorded $14.3&nbsp;million, $12.5&nbsp;million, and
$22.4&nbsp;million in 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively, of
stock-based compensation. Stock-based compensation charges
relate primarily to the exchange of McAfee.com options in
connection with the Company&#146;s acquisition of the publicly
traded minority
</DIV>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">
    Total stock-based compensation</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>14,320</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>12,507</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>22,404</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Exchange of McAfee.com options.</I> On September&nbsp;13,
2002, the Company acquired the minority interest in McAfee.com.
McAfee.com option holders received options for 0.675 of a share
of the Company&#146;s common stock plus $8.00 in cash, $11.85
after applying the option exchange ratio, which is paid to the
option holder upon exercise of the option and without interest.
McAfee.com options to purchase&nbsp;4.1&nbsp;million shares were
converted into options to purchase&nbsp;2.8&nbsp;million shares
of the Company&#146;s common stock. The assumed options have
been accounted for under the guidance in EITF Issue
No.&nbsp;00-23, <I>&#147;Issues Related to the Accounting for
Stock Compensation under APB Opinion No.&nbsp;25,&#148;</I> and
FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;44 (&#147;FIN&nbsp;44&#148;),
<I>&#147;Accounting for Certain Transactions Involving Stock
Compensation&nbsp;&#151; an Interpretation of APB Opinion
No.&nbsp;25.&#148;</I> Accordingly, these options are subject to
variable accounting treatment, which means that a compensation
charge has been measured initially at the date of the closing of
the acquisition and then remeasured at the end of each reporting
period.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The initial charge was based on the excess of the closing price
of the Company&#146;s common stock over the exercise price of
the options plus the $11.85&nbsp;per share payable in cash. This
compensation charge has been and will be remeasured using the
same methodology until the earlier of the date of exercise,
forfeiture or cancellation without replacement. This
compensation charge is recorded as an expense over the remaining
vesting period of the options using the accelerated method of
amortization under FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;28,
<I>&#147;Accounting for Stock Appreciation Rights and Other
Variable Stock Option or Award Plans.&#148;</I> For those
options that were fully vested at the date of the closing of the
acquisition, the Company immediately recorded compensation
expense of $10.5&nbsp;million. Charges related to unvested
options are recorded as deferred stock-based compensation in
stockholders equity in the consolidated balance sheet, and
recognized as expense as the options vest.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During 2004, 2003 and 2002, the Company recorded charges of
approximately $6.7&nbsp;million, $3.4&nbsp;million and
$16.1&nbsp;million, including the $10.5&nbsp;million described
above, respectively, related to exchanged options subject to
variable accounting. These stock-based compensation charges were
based on the Company&#146;s closing stock prices of $28.93,
$15.04 and $16.09 on December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002,
respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company had
outstanding exchanged options to acquire approximately
0.4&nbsp;million
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">110

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>MCAFEE, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
shares subject to this variable accounting. Further fluctuations
in the stock price may result in significant additional stock
based compensation charges in future periods.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Former Employees.</I> In November and December 2003, the
Company extended the vesting period of two employees and also
extended the period after which vesting ends to exercise their
options. These employees&#146; options continued to vest after
termination and their exercise period was extended an additional
90&nbsp;days. The Company recorded a one time stock-based
compensation charge of approximately $0.1&nbsp;million in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As a result of the sale of the Company&#146;s Sniffer product
line in July 2004, the Company modified the stock option
agreements of several Sniffer executives by accelerating the
vesting of their unvested outstanding options. The Company
recorded a stock-based compensation charge of approximately
$1.0&nbsp;million in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In October 2002, the Company terminated the employment of four
former McAfee.com executives. These executives held McAfee.com
exchanged options, which are subject to variable accounting as
discussed above. Upon termination, the options were modified in
accordance with a change in control provision. As a result, the
Company recorded a stock compensation charge of approximately
$1.1&nbsp;million and $9.9&nbsp;million in 2003 and 2002,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In July 2002, one of the Company&#146;s employees became a
non-employee, but continued to provide services to the Company.
As he was allowed to continue to vest his options, the Company
recorded a stock-based compensation charge corresponding to the
fair market value of his vested options. The Company recorded
stock-based compensation of $0.2&nbsp;million in 2002.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>New and Existing Executives and Employees.</I> In January
2002, the Company&#146;s board of directors approved a grant of
50,000&nbsp;shares of restricted stock to its chief executive
officer. The price of the underlying shares is $0.01&nbsp;per
share. The shares will vest and the Company&#146;s right to
repurchase such shares will lapse as follows: 3,000 vested as of
the grant date and 47,000 are restricted until January&nbsp;15,
2005. The fair value of the restricted stock was determined to
be approximately $1.4&nbsp;million and was determined based on
the difference between the exercise price of the restricted
stock and the fair value of the common stock on January&nbsp;15,
2002. During 2004, 2003 and 2002, the Company recorded
approximately $0.4&nbsp;million, $0.4&nbsp;million and
$0.5&nbsp;million related to stock-based compensation associated
with the chief executive officer&#146;s 2002 restricted stock
grant.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In September 2004, the Company&#146;s chief financial officer
and chief operating officer announced that he was retiring from
the Company effective December&nbsp;31, 2004. Under the terms of
his transition agreement, his options were modified such that
all remaining unvested outstanding stock options would
immediately vest on December&nbsp;31, 2004 under specified
conditions. The total stock based compensation charge related to
this modification was approximately $1.3&nbsp;million, which was
recorded as expense in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the acquisition of Foundstone in October
2004, the Company exchanged options to purchase shares of its
common stock for Foundstone stock options. The fair value of the
Company&#146;s stock options was included in the Foundstone
purchase price. In accordance with FIN&nbsp;44, the Company
recorded $2.3&nbsp;million of deferred stock-based compensation
related to the exchange of unvested stock options which are
subject to vesting provisions as employment services are
provided by the former Foundstone employees. The unvested stock
options granted to Foundstone employees vest over periods
ranging through 2008. The Company recorded stock-based
compensation of $0.2&nbsp;million in 2004 related to the
unvested stock options exchanged in the Foundstone acquisition.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On January&nbsp;3, 2001, the Company entered into an employment
agreement with its current chief executive officer. In
accordance with the terms of the agreement, the Company issued
400,000&nbsp;shares of restricted stock to its chief executive
officer. The price of the underlying shares was $0.01&nbsp;per
share. The shares vested and the Company&#146;s right to
repurchase such shares lapsed as follows: 12.5% on the first
four quarterly anniversaries of employment and the remaining 50%
on the second year anniversary of employment. The fair value of
the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">111

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>MCAFEE, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
restricted stock was determined to be approximately
$2.0&nbsp;million and was estimated based on the difference
between the exercise price of the restricted stock and the fair
value of the Company&#146;s common stock on the employment
commencement date. During 2002, the Company recorded
approximately $1.0&nbsp;million in stock-based compensation.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Extended life of vested options held by terminated
employees.</I> In connection with the Foundstone acquisition,
the Company exchanged vested options to purchase shares of its
common stock for vested Foundstone options. Certain Foundstone
employees terminated their employment in October 2004 subsequent
to the acquisition. Under the terms of their options, the
terminated employees had 90&nbsp;days to exercise their options
before they would expire. The Company determined prior to the
end of 2004 that it would not be able to file the required
public company reports with the SEC that would allow the
terminated Foundstone employees to exercise their options within
the 90&nbsp;day period. On December&nbsp;7, 2004, the Company
extended the expiration date of the options through the end of
January 2005. In accordance with FIN&nbsp;44, this modification
was considered to result in a new measurement of compensation
cost as if the options were newly granted. The compensation
charge was calculated based on the difference between the
Company&#146;s closing stock price on December&nbsp;7, 2004, the
date of modification, and the closing stock price on the date of
the Foundstone acquisition. The Company recorded a stock-based
compensation charge of $1.0&nbsp;million in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In March 2003, the Company announced that the filing of its
Form&nbsp;10-K for 2002 would be postponed in order to restate
prior financial results for 2000, 1999 and 1998. As a result,
effective April&nbsp;9, 2003, the Company suspended all
exercises of stock options until the 2002 Form&nbsp;10-K and all
required quarterly reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q were filed with the
SEC, as these reports are incorporated by reference into the
securities registration statements for each of the stock option
plans. The period during which all stock option exercises were
suspended was known as the blackout period. Due to the blackout
period, the Company extended the exercisability of any options
that would otherwise terminate during the blackout period for a
period of time equal to a specified period after termination of
the blackout period. Accordingly, the Company recorded a
stock-based compensation charge on the date the options should
have terminated based on the intrinsic value of the option on
the modification date and the option price. The Company recorded
stock-based compensation charges of approximately
$0.1&nbsp;million and $3.7&nbsp;million for 2004 and 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Extended Vesting Term of Options.</I> In the second quarter
of 2002, the Company recorded a one-time stock-based
compensation charge of approximately $0.2&nbsp;million as a
result of the modification of the terms of the options
previously granted to certain employees.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Extended period of Employee Stock Purchase Plan.</I> In March
2003, the Company announced that the filing of its
Form&nbsp;10-K for 2002 would be postponed in order to restate
prior financial results for 2000, 1999 and 1998. As a result,
effective April&nbsp;9, 2003, the Company suspended all stock
purchases until the 2002 Form&nbsp;10-K and all required
quarterly reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q were filed with the SEC, as
these reports are incorporated by reference into the securities
registration statements for the 2002 Employee Stock Purchase
Plan (&#147;2002 Purchase Plan&#148;). The period during which
all stock purchases were suspended was known as the blackout
period. Due to the blackout period, the Company extended the
purchase period of the 2002 Purchase Plan that would otherwise
had been purchased on July&nbsp;31, 2003. Accordingly, during
2003, the Company recorded a stock-based compensation charge of
approximately $3.9&nbsp;million for the extended period of the
2002 Purchase Plan. The blackout period ended in November 2003,
and therefore no additional stock-based compensation will be
recorded.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Shares Purchased Outside Employee Stock Purchase Plan.</I> On
January&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company experienced a shortfall in
the number of shares available under the 1994 Employee Qualified
Stock Purchase Plan to meet the requirements of the open
purchase period. Although the Company reduced the number of
shares plan participants could purchase by a pro rata amount,
additional shares were required to be purchased outside of the
plan in order to meet this shortfall. As a result, the Company
recorded a one-time stock-based compensation charge of
approximately $0.1&nbsp;million in 2002. The charge was based on
the difference between
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">112

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>MCAFEE, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
the fair value of the shares purchased outside of the plan and
the price the shares were sold to plan participants.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>Repriced Options.</I> On April&nbsp;22, 1999, the Company
offered to substantially all of its employees, excluding
executive officers, the right to cancel certain outstanding
stock options and receive new options with an exercise price of
$11.063, the then current fair value of the stock. Options to
purchase a total of 9.5&nbsp;million shares were cancelled and
the same number of new options were granted. These new options
vest at the same rate that they would have vested under previous
option plans and are subject to variable accounting.
Accordingly, the Company has and will continue to remeasure
compensation cost for these repriced options until these options
are exercised, cancelled, or forfeited without replacement. The
first valuation period began July&nbsp;1, 2000.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The amount of stock-based compensation recorded was and will be
based on any excess of the closing stock price at the end of the
reporting period or date of exercise, forfeiture or cancellation
without replacement, if earlier, over the fair value of the
Company&#146;s common stock on July&nbsp;1, 2000, which was
$20.375. The resulting compensation charge to earnings is
recorded over the remaining vesting period, using the
accelerated method of amortization required by FASB
Interpretation&nbsp;28, <I>&#147;Accounting for Stock
Appreciation Rights and Other Variable Stock Option or Award
Plans&nbsp;&#151; an Interpretation of APB Opinions No.&nbsp;15
and 25.&#148; </I>At December&nbsp;31, 2004, these options were
fully vested. Depending upon movements in the market value of
the Company&#146;s common stock, this variable accounting
treatment can result in additional stock-based compensation
charges in future periods until the options are exercised,
forfeited or cancelled.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During 2004, the Company recorded a stock-based compensation
charge of $3.3&nbsp;million, and during 2002, the Company
recorded a credit to earnings of approximately
$6.5&nbsp;million. For 2004 and 2002, the Company&#146;s
stock-based compensation charge (credit)&nbsp;was based on
year-end per share prices of its stock of $28.93 and $16.09,
respectively. There was no charge or credit recorded by the
Company in 2003 as the stock price was below $20.375 as of
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and throughout 2003. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company had 0.3&nbsp;million options
outstanding subject to variable accounting.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company also incurred an initial stock-based compensation
charge in connection with the initial issuance of the repriced
options. This charge was calculated based on the difference
between the exercise price of the new options and their market
value on the date of acceptance by employees. Approximately
$1.0&nbsp;million was expensed during 2002.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>17.</B></TD>
    <TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Approximately $3.6&nbsp;million of the provision for income
taxes in 2003 was reflected as part of the cumulative effect of
a change in accounting principal in the consolidated statement
of income.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">114

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>MCAFEE, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company has net operating loss
carryovers for federal income tax purposes of approximately
$74.2&nbsp;million. These net operating loss carryovers relate
to acquisitions and are limited in the amount that can be
recognized in any one year, and have expiration dates ranging
from 2008 to 2024. The net decrease in the valuation allowance
primarily relates to the utilization of foreign tax credits and
net operating loss carryforwards from acquisitions for which
there was uncertainty of future utilization prior to 2004. This
decrease was partially offset by approximately a
$2.2&nbsp;million valuation allowance recorded related to
deferred tax assets of Foundstone. Management believes that it
is more likely than not that the results of future operations
will generate sufficient taxable income to realize the net
deferred tax assets, other than certain acquired net operating
loss and credit carryforwards and certain other foreign tax
credits for which a valuation allowance has been provided.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
United States income taxes have not been provided for on a
cumulative total of approximately $341.3&nbsp;million of
earnings of certain non-U.S.&nbsp;subsidiaries, as the
Company&#146;s historical intent has been to reinvest these
earnings indefinitely in operations outside the U.S.&nbsp;See
&#147;Recent Accounting Pronouncements and Guidance&#148;<B><I>
</I></B>in Note&nbsp;2 of the Consolidated Financial Statements
for discussion of recent legislation regarding the repatriation
of foreign earnings.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s effective tax rate on income before income
taxes differs from the U.S.&nbsp;Federal statutory tax rate as
follows (in thousands):
</DIV>

    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In 2004, the Company realized the benefit of certain tax
deductions related to a prior period acquisition. The
$27.0&nbsp;million benefit has been recorded as a credit to
additional paid in capital in the consolidated statement of
stockholders&#146; equity in 2004 as the acquisition was
accounted for under the &#147;pooling of interests&#148; method.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>18.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Net Income Per Share</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>19.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Business Segment and Major Customer Information</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company has concluded that it has one business and operates
in one industry, developing, marketing, distributing and
supporting computer security solutions for large enterprises,
governments, small and medium sized business and consumer users,
as well as resellers and distributors. Management measures
profitability based on the Company&#146;s five geographic
regions: North America; EMEA; Japan; Asia-Pacific (excluding
Japan) and Latin America. The regions are evidence of the
operating structure of the Company&#146;s internal organization.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">116

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>MCAFEE, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company markets and sells, through its geographic regions,
anti-virus and security software, hardware and services; network
management software, hardware and services; and help desk
software and services. These products and services are marketed
and sold worldwide primarily through resellers, distributors,
systems integrators retailers, and directly by the Company. In
addition, the Company offers web sites, which provide suites of
on-line products and services personalized for the user based on
the users&#146; PC configuration, attached peripherals and
resident software. The Company also offers managed security and
availability applications to corporations and governments on the
Internet.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The accounting policies of the businesses and geographic
segments are the same as disclosed in Note&nbsp;2. To reconcile
to the consolidated financial statements, where applicable,
&#147;Corporate&#148; represents costs and expenses associated
with corporate activities. Corporate activities include general
and administrative expenses and corporate marketing expenses of
$65.0&nbsp;million, $61.9&nbsp;million, and $37.3&nbsp;million
in 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively; stock-based compensation
charges; and acquisition, restructuring and other related costs.
These corporate expenses are not considered attributable to any
specific geographic region. The $25.0&nbsp;million litigation
reimbursement received in 2004 and the $70.0&nbsp;million
litigation charge incurred in 2002 were recorded in North
America. Summarized financial information concerning the
Company&#146;s net revenue and operating income by geographic
region is as follows (in thousands):
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
At December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, one customer had an accounts
receivable balance which comprised 23% and 22%, respectively, of
the Company&#146;s total accounts receivable balance. During
2004, 2003 and 2002, one customer accounted for 22%, 24% and
25%, respectively, of the total net revenue for each year.
During 2004 and 2002, another customer accounted for 11% and
10%, respectively, of the net revenue. The net revenue derived
from these customers is reported primarily in the Company&#146;s
North American and EMEA geographic segments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>20.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Litigation</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>General</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
From time to time, the Company has been subject to litigation
including the pending litigation described below. The
Company&#146;s current estimated range of liability related to
some of the pending litigation below is based on claims for
which management can estimate the amount and range of loss. The
Company has recorded the minimum estimated liability related to
those claims, where there is a range of loss. Because of the
uncertainties related to the range of loss on the remaining
pending litigation, management is unable to make a reasonable
estimate of the liability that could result from an unfavorable
outcome. As additional information becomes available, the
Company will assess its potential liability and revise its
estimates. Pending or future litigation could be costly, could
cause the diversion of management&#146;s attention and could
upon resolution, have a material adverse effect on the business,
results of operations, financial condition and cash flow.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">119

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>MCAFEE, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition, the Company is engaged in certain legal and
administrative proceedings incidental to its normal business
activities and believes that these matters will not have a
material adverse effect on the Company&#146;s financial
position, results of operations or cash flows.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Securities Cases</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In September 2003, the Company entered into a settlement
agreement with the plaintiffs in the <I>In re Network
Associates, Inc.&nbsp;II Securities Litigation</I>, which was
originally filed in September 2001. Under the settlement
agreement the Company paid $70.0&nbsp;million, which was
recorded as litigation settlement in the consolidated statement
of income for 2002. The settlement was approved by the court in
February 2004, and the case was dismissed with prejudice to all
parties and claims. In 2004, the Company received approximately
$25.0&nbsp;million from its insurance carriers related to this
litigation, which was recorded as litigation reimbursement in
the consolidated statement of income for 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Certain investment bank underwriters, the Company, and certain
of its directors and officers have been named in a putative
class action for violation of the federal securities laws in the
United States District Court for the Southern District of New
York, captioned <I>In re McAfee.com Corp. Initial Public
Offering Securities Litigation</I>, 01 Civ.&nbsp;7034 (SAS).
This is one of a number of cases challenging underwriting
practices in the initial public offerings (&#147;IPOs&#148;) of
more than 300&nbsp;companies. These cases have been coordinated
for pretrial proceedings as <I>In re Initial Public Offering
Securities Litigation</I>, 21&nbsp;MC&nbsp;92 (SAS). Plaintiffs
generally allege that certain underwriters engaged in
undisclosed and improper underwriting activities, namely the
receipt of excessive brokerage commissions and customer
agreements regarding post-offering purchases of stock in
exchange for allocations of IPO shares. Plaintiffs also allege
that various investment bank securities analysts issued false
and misleading analyst reports. The complaint against the
Company claims that the purported improper underwriting
activities were not disclosed in the registration statements for
McAfee.com&#146;s IPO and seeks unspecified damages on behalf of
a purported class of persons who purchased the Company&#146;s
securities or sold put options during the time period from
December&nbsp;1, 1999 to December&nbsp;6, 2000. On
February&nbsp;19, 2003 the Court issued an Opinion and Order
dismissing certain of the claims against the Company with leave
to amend. A settlement proposal was accepted by the Company on
July&nbsp;15, 2003 and is awaiting Court approval. Under this
settlement proposal, the Company may assign its claims against
certain underwriters to the plaintiffs, and the Company would be
dismissed from the lawsuit without paying any monetary damages.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I>Other Matters</I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On June&nbsp;6, 2002, Paul Cozza filed a Complaint in the United
States District Court, District of Massachusetts alleging breach
of contract, fraud and bad faith arising out of a dispute
concerning the licensing of certain technology used in the
Company&#146;s Virex 6.1 product. The Complaint seeks royalties
on the Company&#146;s sale of Virex 6.1 products from
January&nbsp;1, 2002 to the present. The Company filed papers in
opposition to the Complaint and asserted various defenses. The
Company also moved to compel arbitration, which was denied by
the District Court and the First Circuit Court of Appeals. In
September 2004 the parties filed cross-motions for partial
summary judgment on liability, but not damages, issues relating
to whether the contract claims extend beyond the Virex 6.1
product. The District Court has heard argument on the pending
cross-motions for partial summary judgment but has not yet
issued any decision.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
On March&nbsp;22, 2002, the Securities and Exchange Commission
notified the Company that it has commenced a &#147;Formal Order
of Private Investigation&#148; into the Company&#146;s
accounting practices. The SEC investigation is continuing, and
the Company continues to provide documents and information to
the SEC.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>21.</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B>Related Party Transactions</B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Under the terms of the amended and restated employment agreement
for Mr.&nbsp;George Samenuk, Chairman of the Board and Chief
Executive Officer, the Company agreed to loan Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk
the funds
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">120

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">
<B>MCAFEE, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
necessary to pay the taxes due on each vesting date for the
400,000&nbsp;shares of restricted stock granted to
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk on January&nbsp;3, 2001. In addition, the
Company agreed to loan Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk the funds necessary to
pay the taxes due on the 3,000&nbsp;shares of stock granted to
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk on January&nbsp;15, 2002. In accordance with
the provisions of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, no additional
loans were made to Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk after July&nbsp;30, 2002 and
no material modifications were made to any loan outstanding on
that date.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In total, the Company extended five separate loans to
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, four loans in an
aggregate amount of approximately $955,000 were outstanding. The
loans each had a two-year maturity and bore interest at the
applicable federal rate. The loans were full recourse and
secured by Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s restricted stock and
3,000&nbsp;shares of stock. The last remaining loan was fully
repaid in October 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>

    <B>Subsequent Events</B></TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In March 2005, the Company repurchased approximately
2.0&nbsp;million shares of its common stock in the open market
for approximately $47.4&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(1)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <I>Provision for Doubtful Accounts, Net.</I> The provision for
    doubtful accounts, net consists of our estimates with respect to
    the uncollectibility of our receivables, net of recoveries of
    amounts previously written off. Our management must make
    estimates of the uncollectibility of our accounts receivables.
    Management specifically analyzes accounts receivable and
    analyzes historical bad debts, customer concentrations, customer
    credit-worthiness, current economic trends and changes in our
    customer payment terms when evaluating the adequacy of the
    allowance for doubtful accounts.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(2)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The allowance for doubtful accounts in the consolidated balance
    sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2003 is net of the
    $0.2&nbsp;million allowance for Magic, which is included in
    assets held for sale.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<TR style="font-size: 1pt;">
    <TD width="45%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 8pt;">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap><B>Provision for</B></TD><TD></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt;">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>(3)&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <I>Provision for Sales Returns and Allowances.</I> The provision
    for sales returns and allowances consists of our estimates of
    potential future product returns related to current period
    product revenue, and specific provisions for distributor,
    reseller, and retailer sales incentives (&#147;allowances&#148;)
    that are reductions in the revenue to be realized. Management
    analyzes historical returns, current economic trends, and
    changes in customer demand and acceptance of our products when
    evaluating the adequacy of the sales returns and allowances.
    Significant management judgments and estimates must be made and
    used in connection with establishing the sales returns and
    allowances in any accounting period. Material differences may
    result in the amount and timing of our revenue for any period if
    management made different judgments or utilized different
    estimates.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt;">126

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="right" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>EXHIBIT 10.46</B>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>McAfee, Inc.</B>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Independent Director Cash Compensation Plan</B></DIV>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Annual Retainer Schedule</B>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="77%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD nowrap align="left"><B>Category</B></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom"><!-- Blank Space -->
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">&nbsp;</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #cceeff">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Board Retainer</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">40,000</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Committee Chairman additional retainer</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">10,000</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #cceeff">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Lead Independent Director additional retainer</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">10,000</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">All fees are paid quarterly. In addition, McAfee reimburses directors for reasonable travel and
other expenses incurred in attending meetings or participating in professional development and
education activities.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Furthermore, under McAfee&#146;s current Stock Option Plan for Outside Directors non-employee directors
are automatically granted an option to purchase 50,000 shares of our common stock when they first
become a director. Each year after the initial grant they are entitled to receive an additional
option grant to purchase up to 25,000 shares of our common stock. All options under this plan are
granted at the fair market value on the date of grant. The initial grant vests one-third each year
over three years from the date of grant. The subsequent grants vest in full three years from the
date of grant. All options granted under this plan become fully exercisable in the event of certain
mergers, sales of assets or sales of the majority of our voting stock.




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">
</DIV>
